elements.content: Under the guidance of self-assembly, a series of Cu­(I)/Cu­(II) metal–organic complexes (MOCs), [Cu3(TCPB)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (1), {[Cu2(TCPB) (DMA)­(H2O)]·H2O} n (2), [(Cu8I8) (Cu6I6)0.5(DABCO)3·2H2O] n (3), and [(Cu4I8) (DABCO)2·6H2O]2n (4) (H3TCPB = 1,3,5-tris­(4-carbonylphenyloxy)-benzene, DABCO = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane) have been synthesized and characterized. Complexes 1 and 2 are driven by noncovalent interactions to assemble into supramolecular metal–organic frameworks. Considering H3TCPB ligand with different geometrical structures, 1 forms an Eiffel Tower shaped supramolecular cage based on equilateral triangle shaped trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit, which possesses effective free volume about 24.7%. Changing the solvent, 2 displays 1D chain structure based on linear bivalent copper trinuclear {Cu3(CO2)2(H2O)2}. When inducing auxiliary ligand DABCO, H3TCPB serves as additive agent and 3 consists of mixed CuI clusters (Cu6I6 and Cu8I8) and plays a 2D layer, which is a rare example. Without additive agent, 4 exhibits a 2D cuprous iodide layer, where 3 and 4 are two novel copper-iodide supramolecular isomers. Owing to large voids in the framework, 1 can serve as a host for use in dye adsorption. The experiment results show that different dyes, including “just right size” Crystal Violet (CV) can be rapidly adsorbed by 1, but smaller Indigo Blue (IB), Methylene Blue (MEB), Methyl Orange (MO), and larger Rhodamine B (RB) and Methyl Blue (MB) can hardly be adsorbed. Surprisingly, 1 also preferentially adsorbs (or separates) CV from MO and CV in their mixed aqueous solution with fast response and high sensitivity (<16.13 s) by the theoretical calculation. Moreover, absorption spectra demonstrate the band gaps of 3 and 4 are 2.37 and 1.98 eV, respectively. When increasing the dimensions of inorganic compositions in cluster–organic complexes, it could exert a remarkable influence on the band gap.

elements.content: A series of Cu­(I)/Cu­(II) metal−organic complexes display fascinating structures under the guidance of self-assembly. Compound 1 exhibits highly selective absorption CV, while 3 and 4 show the unique semiconductive nature.

elements.content: Dyes are widely used due to their amazing color in food, textile, paper, and pharmaceutical industries, as well as research laboratories, etc. The application also brings pollution to the water and may cause harm to human health. Crystal Violet (CV) is one of the well-known cationic dyes, which has widespread use as a fungicide in aquaculture, but many countries have banned or restricted their use in low concentrations because they have a high toxicity and residual characteristics as well as teratogenic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic effects. It is extremely important to remove the poisonous dyes from industrial effluents before discharging them into the natural environments. To our knowledge, there are several methods to remove the dyes to achieve friendly environment, such as biological degradation, physical adsorption, chemical catalysis biological, etc. To achieve fast response and accurate encapsulation CV, it is crucial to design adsorbent materials matching with the CV size to ensure the immobilization of guest CV within host framework. In this regards, metal–organic complexes (MOCs) featuring tunable size, shape, and porous structure through the modification of the organic linker and noncovalent interactions under self-assembly method exhibit excellent physicochemical stability and reusability as storage media and appear to be one of the most effective solids for the absorption of CV.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Dyes are widely used due to their amazing color in food, textile, paper, and pharmaceutical industries, as well as research laboratories, etc. The application also brings pollution to the water and may cause harm to human health. Crystal Violet (CV) is one of the well-known cationic dyes, which has widespread use as a fungicide in aquaculture, but many countries have banned or restricted their use in low concentrations because they have a high toxicity and residual characteristics as well as teratogenic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic effects. It is extremely important to remove the poisonous dyes from industrial effluents before discharging them into the natural environments. To our knowledge, there are several methods to remove the dyes to achieve friendly environment, such as biological degradation, physical adsorption, chemical catalysis biological, etc. To achieve fast response and accurate encapsulation CV, it is crucial to design adsorbent materials matching with the CV size to ensure the immobilization of guest CV within host framework. In this regards, metal-organic complexes (MOCs) featuring tunable size, shape, and porous structure through the modification of the organic linker and noncovalent interactions under self-assembly method exhibit excellent physicochemical stability and reusability as storage media and appear to be one of the most effective solids for the absorption of CV.

elements.content: Simultaneously, MOCs with ordered porous structure and tunable functionalities applications have proven to be valuable platforms for designing new solids in the electronics industry, which the electronic structure of MOCs may be tuned through the organic linker. In the quest for the development of MOCs for electronic applications and devices, much effort has been focused upon making semiconductive MOCs. In 2007, Garcia and co-workers reported on the semiconductor behavior of MOF-5, which has a band gap of 3.4 eV. Until 2015, Usman and co-workers report a new type of Sr-based metal–organic complex and the band gap is 2.3 eV, which can be comparable to that of other commonly used semiconducting materials (e.g., CdSe, CdTe, ZnTe, GaP, etc.). However, understanding of the semiconducting behavior of MOCs is still in the initial stages, and further investigations would be highly desirable. The iodides of d10 cation (CuI) possess flexible μ-I linkage modes, local charge density, metallophillic interactions, and electron-rich feature. These features could display more sensitive response to the spatial and electronic configuration and be regarded as an ideal candidate for the structural directing assembly of MOCs with semiconductor properties.

In 2007, Garcia and co-workers reported on the semiconductor behavior of MOF-5, which has a band gap of 3.4 eV. Until 2015, Usman and co-workers report a new type of Sr-based metal-organic complex and the band gap is 2.3 eV, which can be comparable to that of other commonly used semiconducting materials (e.g., CdSe, CdTe, ZnTe, GaP, etc.). However, understanding of the semiconducting behavior of MOCs is still in the initial stages, and further investigations would be highly desirable. The iodides of d10 cation (CuI) possess flexible μ-I linkage modes, local charge density, metallophillic interactions, and electron-rich feature. These features could display more sensitive response to the spatial and electronic configuration and be regarded as an ideal candidate for the structural directing assembly of MOCs with semiconductor properties.

elements.content: In this context, we used 1,3,5-tris­(4-carbonylphenyloxy)-benzene (H3TCPB), bearing C3 rotating shaft and three flexible rotatable −O– motifs, to successfully construct a pair of MOCs [Cu3(TCPB)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (1) and {[Cu2(TCPB)­(DMA)­(H2O)]·H2O} n (2) through self-assembly method. With the change of ligand torsion angle, 1 and 2 possess different trinuclear units, equilateral triangle shaped [Cu3(CO2)3] and linear {Cu3(CO2)2(H2O)2}, respectively. Another pair of conformational supramolecular isomers [(Cu8I8)­(Cu6I6)0.5(DABCO)3·2H2O] n (3) and [(Cu4I8)­(DABCO)2·6H2O]2n (4) directed by the additive agents (H3TCPB), which are two novel cuprous iodide cluster complexes, where 3 contains Cu6I6 and Cu8I8 building units, and construction of the 2D inorganic layer based on Cu4I3 in 4 (). Self-assembly method may open up an ingenious direction for synthesizing new materials with multifunctionality. Owing to large voids in the framework, exactly, 1 shows fast response for absorption CV and release CV with the help of NH4Cl, easily. Amazingly, 1 can also separate CV from MO and CV in the mixed aqueous solution with fast response and high sensitivity (<16.13 s). However, the band gaps of 2.37 eV for 3 and 1.98 eV for 4 were investigated by the diffuse reflection spectra, and the results have been confirmed when enhancing the dimensions of inorganic compositions in cluster–organic complexes; it could affect the band gap dramatically.

Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Cu3(TCPB)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (1)

A mixture of CuI (0.038 g, 0.20 mmol) and H3TCPB (0.024 g, 0.05 mmol) was treated in CH3CN solvent (6 mL) at ambient temperature. While stirring for 30 min in air, it was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 120 h, and then slowly cooled to ambient condition. Green hexagon-shaped crystals were dried at room temperature (yield ca. 74%, based on H3TCPB). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd. for C54H40Cu3O23 (M  r : 1247.48): C, 51.99; H, 3.23%. Found: C, 51.52; H, 3.22%. IR (cm-1): 3549 (br, s), 3063 (w), 1628 (vs), 1450 (vs), 1410 (vs), 1272 (s), 1222 (vs), 1123 (vs), 1014 (s), 826 (m), 757 (s), 668 (m), 589 (w), 499 (w), 430 (w).

elements.content: Under the guidance of self-assembly, we have successfully obtained four novel Cu­(I)/Cu­(II) complexes from 0D to 2D, the reaction routes and the crystallographic data of complexes 1–4 are shown in and , respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermal stabilities of 1–4 are displayed in Figures S1 and S2. Specific synthetic route is as follows: (1) 1 → 2, the bridging nonmetallic oxygen atom from H3TPCB connect metal center Cu­(II) by bidentate mode, giving rise to the monomer structure of 1. The effect of C3 aromatic carboxylic acid with multifarious coordination modes and different geometries on the resulting various structures cannot be neglected. The flexibility of the asymmetric C 3 aromatic carboxylic acid is the key factor to control the ligand torsion. We exchanged the solvent from CH3CN to the mixed-solvent (DMA–H2O) and obtained the 1D structure of 2; (2) 2 → 3 (effect of H3TPCB ligand acting as additive agents), to design and synthesize higher dimensional complexes, the auxiliary ligands play important roles in the connectivity of multidimensional net due to more coordination sites. Therefore, based on the synthetic procedure of 1 and 2, we introduced DABCO as auxiliary ligand. Surprisingly, we obtained the 2D structure of 3, which is no participation of H3TPCB ligand; (3) 3 → 4 (without H3TPCB ligand acting as additive agents), in order to prove the role of H3TPCB ligand, only using the auxiliary ligand DABCO, 2D layer structure of 4 was obtained, which is different from 3. Both 3 and 4 are supramolecular isomers having identical chemical compositions. In brief, the formation of supramolecular isomers is directed by whether or not the H3TPCB ligand is used as an additive agent in the system. Actually, the isomerism arising from the H3TPCB ligand is fortuitously discovered because the additive is not incorporated in the final crystalline sample of 3. This phenomenon reveals that the microenvironment of the reaction might significantly be affected by H3TPCB ligand, leading to obtain diverse superstructures as compared to those crystallized in the absence of H3TPCB ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characteristic

Under the guidance of self-assembly, we have successfully obtained four novel Cu(I)/Cu(II) complexes from 0D to 2D, the reaction routes and the crystallographic data of complexes 1-4 are shown in  and , respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermal stabilities of 1-4 are displayed in Figures S1 and S2. Specific synthetic route is as follows: (1) 1 → 2, the bridging nonmetallic oxygen atom from H3TPCB connect metal center Cu(II) by bidentate mode, giving rise to the monomer structure of 1. The effect of C3 aromatic carboxylic acid with multifarious coordination modes and different geometries on the resulting various structures cannot be neglected. The flexibility of the asymmetric C 3 aromatic carboxylic acid is the key factor to control the ligand torsion. We exchanged the solvent from CH3CN to the mixed-solvent (DMA-H2O) and obtained the 1D structure of 2; (2) 2 → 3 (effect of H3TPCB ligand acting as additive agents), to design and synthesize higher dimensional complexes, the auxiliary ligands play important roles in the connectivity of multidimensional net due to more coordination sites. Therefore, based on the synthetic procedure of 1 and 2, we introduced DABCO as auxiliary ligand. Surprisingly, we obtained the 2D structure of 3, which is no participation of H3TPCB ligand; (3) 3 → 4 (without H3TPCB ligand acting as additive agents), in order to prove the role of H3TPCB ligand, only using the auxiliary ligand DABCO, 2D layer structure of 4 was obtained, which is different from 3. Both 3 and 4 are supramolecular isomers having identical chemical compositions. In brief, the formation of supramolecular isomers is directed by whether or not the H3TPCB ligand is used as an additive agent in the system. Actually, the isomerism arising from the H3TPCB ligand is fortuitously discovered because the additive is not incorporated in the final crystalline sample of 3. This phenomenon reveals that the microenvironment of the reaction might significantly be affected by H3TPCB ligand, leading to obtain diverse superstructures as compared to those crystallized in the absence of H3TPCB ligand.

X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis indicates that 1 crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group R3̅c, and the asymmetry unit contains one Cu­(II) ion, 1/3 TCPB3– ligand, one coordinated water molecule, and one free water molecule (Figure S3). In the structure, the Cu1 center is quadrangularly coordinated to four oxygen atoms from the bridging carboxylate groups of two TCPB3– ligands, each carboxylate group coordinates with two Cu­(II) ions, adopting chelating bidentate coordination mode. Adjacent two TCPB3– anions coordinated to three Cu­(II) ions to form trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit. Under a close inspection of the trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit, the distances of Cu···Cu are all 3.330 Å, which interact with each other and form an equilateral triangle shape, the master combination in space makes the trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit more steadily. More deeply, the discrete 1 can be described as a supramolecular cage, which looks like the Eiffel Tower (a), and the connection between adjacent cage is confirmed by C4–H4A···O1 (2.984 Å) to form 1D chain structure (b). In addition, 1 shows a 2D supramolecular layer in space through strong C5–H5A···O1 (2.670 Å) (c). Among the adjacent 2D hydrogen-bonded layers, there is the C4–H4A···O1 hydrogen bond in two-dimensional directions, generating a 3D supramolecular framework (d). The cross-section of the channel exhibits maximum dimension of 4.84 × 13.16 Å (considering the van der Waals radii).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures of 1-4 

Crystal Structure of [Cu3(TCPB)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (1)

X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis indicates that 1 crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group R3̅c, and the asymmetry unit contains one Cu(II) ion, 1/3 TCPB3- ligand, one coordinated water molecule, and one free water molecule (Figure S3). In the structure, the Cu1 center is quadrangularly coordinated to four oxygen atoms from the bridging carboxylate groups of two TCPB3- ligands, each carboxylate group coordinates with two Cu(II) ions, adopting chelating bidentate coordination mode. Adjacent two TCPB3- anions coordinated to three Cu(II) ions to form trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit. Under a close inspection of the trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit, the distances of Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu are all 3.330 Å, which interact with each other and form an equilateral triangle shape, the master combination in space makes the trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit more steadily. More deeply, the discrete 1 can be described as a supramolecular cage, which looks like the Eiffel Tower (a), and the connection between adjacent cage is confirmed by C4-H4A⋅⋅⋅O1 (2.984 Å) to form 1D chain structure (b). In addition, 1 shows a 2D supramolecular layer in space through strong C5-H5A⋅⋅⋅O1 (2.670 Å) (c). Among the adjacent 2D hydrogen-bonded layers, there is the C4-H4A⋅⋅⋅O1 hydrogen bond in two-dimensional directions, generating a 3D supramolecular framework (d). The cross-section of the channel exhibits maximum dimension of 4.84 × 13.16 Å (considering the van der Waals radii).

elements.content: Different from the case for 1, 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. There are three Cu­(II) ions, one TCPB3– ligand, one DMA molecule, one lattice water molecule, and one free water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 2 (Figure S4). The coordination mode of TCPB3– in 2 is μ5 = η1:η1:η1:η2:η1. In this structure, a pair of triple carboxylate and two H2O molecules are connected to one central metal Cu3 and two terminal metal Cu1 to form a trinuclear {Cu3(CO2)2(H2O)2} (Cu···Cu 3.002 Å), and such three Cu­(II) centers are completely collinear (∠Cu–Cu–Cu = 180.00°). Each of the {Cu3(CO2)2(H2O)2} units is linked to Cu­(CO2)2 unit to afford a 1D chain (Figure S5). After carefully observing the structure it can be seen that these 1D chains are interconnected to form a 3D supramolecular architecture by hydrogen bonding interactions (). Through C11B–H11B···O5 hydrogen bonding, the 1D chains are linked to generate 2D layers in the ac plane, and through C13–H13A···O15 hydrogen bonding, the 1D chains are linked to obtain another 2D layers in the ab plane, of which the distances are 2.658 and 2.781 Å, respectively. These 2D layers are further connected in two directions by the two above hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 3D supramolecular architecture. There also exists intermolecular π···π interaction with the distance about 3.859 Å in face-to-face manner to form a 2D layer (Figure S6), which provides further stabilization in 2.

elements.content: Adopting the common ligand H3TCPB in the structures of 1 and 2, it is beneficial to reorganize the covalent bond and reassemble the metal–ligand connectivity due to freely rotate around nonmetallic bridging oxygen atoms between two benzene rings. As expected, through changing the mixed solvent, we get a novel structure of 2. The flexibility of symmetric triangle-shaped multicarboxylate ligand is the key factor in the ligand torsion. Notably, both structures of 1 and 2 contain similar Cu­(II) coordination geometry and ligand connection mode, and the subtle structural difference only arises from the configuration of H3TCPB ligand and trinuclear SBUs. The dihedral angles between the central benzene group and three sloping benzene arms in H3TCPB are 63.82° for 1 and 61.14°, 77.50°, 71.87° for 2. In the structure of 2, 1-carboxylic group is slightly twisted from 63.82° to 61.14°; coordination mode and the bond lengths show almost no change. Meanwhile, 3-position and 5-position benzene rings rotate around the flexible −O– shaft, allowing the carboxylate group to dissociate from original metal center Cu2+. 3-Carboxylic and 5-carboxylic groups show a larger twist from 63.82° to 77.50° and 71.87°, respectively (a,b). The distance between O and Cu is much longer, resulting in a destroyed original triangle-shaped structure. The total void value of the channel without solvent molecules are estimated to be 8406.0 Å3 and 1511.3 Å3 by PLATON software, the effective free volumes are 24.7% and 3.1% per unit cell in 1 and 2, respectively. Furthermore, the different porous features in crystallography could effect on their sorption behaviors as well. Subsequently, accompanied by the torsion of the ligand, trinuclear [Cu3(CO2)3] unit shaped an equilateral triangle in 1 changed into {Cu3(CO2)2(H2O)2} linear unit in 2 (c,d).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis demonstrated that 3 exhibits a 2D layer built up from Cu6I6 and Cu8I8 clusters (a,b) by DABCO ligand. In Cu6I6 cluster, four Cu­(I) ions are participated in tetrahedral geometry, and each Cu­(I) ion is coordinated by a nitrogen atom and three iodide ions. The average Cu–Cu distance is 2.885 Å, and the distances of Cu–I bonds are ranging from 2.559 to 2.864 Å (Table S1), all of which are similar to those reported for other [CuI] n cluster complexes. All iodide atoms adopt the trigonal pyramidal coordination modes in Cu6I6 cluster. The Cu6I6 cluster may be regarded as a hexagon prism. In Cu8I8 cluster, all of the center metal Cu­(I) display tetrahedral geometries, but the tiny differences exist in coordination environments: four with I3-DABCO donor sets, two with I3–H2O donor set, and two with I4 donor sets. The Cu8I8 cluster looks like a double-cubane Cu4I4 cluster, which is linked by two Cu–I bonds. Subsequently, the structure of 3 reveals dual features of neutral [CuI] n clusters, and the combination of hexagonal prism (Cu6I6) and double-cubandue (Cu8I8) is extremely rare. So far, only two copper iodine with Cu6I6 and Cu8I8 mixed clusters have been found. Each Cu6I6 unit connects four Cu8I8 units, and each Cu8I8 unit connects two Cu6I6 and two Cu8I8 through DABCO ligand, resulting in a 2D layer in the bc plane (c). Because H3TPCB ligand acts as additive agent, although it is not participated in coordination, it occupied the position of the hole with the effective free volume of 30.3% (11766 Å3) per unit cell in 3, after removing the lattice guest solvents by PLATON. Note that the axial water molecules protrude outside of the layer (d), which prevents the linkage between the adjacent layers to form 3D framework.

Crystal Structure of [(Cu8I8)(Cu6I6)0.5(DABCO)3⋅2H2O] n  (3)

Single-crystal X-ray analysis demonstrated that 3 exhibits a 2D layer built up from Cu6I6 and Cu8I8 clusters (a,b) by DABCO ligand. In Cu6I6 cluster, four Cu(I) ions are participated in tetrahedral geometry, and each Cu(I) ion is coordinated by a nitrogen atom and three iodide ions. The average Cu-Cu distance is 2.885 Å, and the distances of Cu-I bonds are ranging from 2.559 to 2.864 Å (Table S1), all of which are similar to those reported for other [CuI] n  cluster complexes. All iodide atoms adopt the trigonal pyramidal coordination modes in Cu6I6 cluster. The Cu6I6 cluster may be regarded as a hexagon prism. In Cu8I8 cluster, all of the center metal Cu(I) display tetrahedral geometries, but the tiny differences exist in coordination environments: four with I3-DABCO donor sets, two with I3-H2O donor set, and two with I4 donor sets. The Cu8I8 cluster looks like a double-cubane Cu4I4 cluster, which is linked by two Cu-I bonds. Subsequently, the structure of 3 reveals dual features of neutral [CuI] n  clusters, and the combination of hexagonal prism (Cu6I6) and double-cubandue (Cu8I8) is extremely rare. So far, only two copper iodine with Cu6I6 and Cu8I8 mixed clusters have been found. Each Cu6I6 unit connects four Cu8I8 units, and each Cu8I8 unit connects two Cu6I6 and two Cu8I8 through DABCO ligand, resulting in a 2D layer in the bc plane (c). Because H3TPCB ligand acts as additive agent, although it is not participated in coordination, it occupied the position of the hole with the effective free volume of 30.3% (11766 Å3) per unit cell in 3, after removing the lattice guest solvents by PLATON. Note that the axial water molecules protrude outside of the layer (d), which prevents the linkage between the adjacent layers to form 3D framework.

elements.content: Metal–organic complex 4 crystallizes in a rhombohedral space group R3̅c and exhibits a 2D layer network. The asymmetric unit of 4 has nine iodine ions, four unique copper­(I) ions, one coordinated DABCO ligand, and one free DABCO ligand (a). In 4, center mental Cu1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three I ions and one N atom from DABCO, and Cu2 is coordinated by four I ions. The distance of Cu–Cu interaction is ca. 2.919(4) Å, which is similar to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu atoms, indicating the existence of weak Cu–Cu interactions. Each iodine ion adopts μ2-I or μ3-I bridging modes. A prominent structural feature of 4 is four Cu ions connected by three I atoms resulting in an unique single cap hexagon-like Cu4I3 unit (b), while connection of the Cu4I3 units by bridging iodine ion results in 6-ring window with six Cu4I3 clusters. The diameter of the 6-ring is approximately 1.48 nm. Every 6-ring is surrounded by another six 6-rings, which form a 2D layer without effective free volume (c,d). Note that even by omitting DABCO ligand, only by inorganic compositions (Cu and I), the 2D layer can be constructed.

The asymmetric unit of 4 has nine iodine ions, four unique copper(I) ions, one coordinated DABCO ligand, and one free DABCO ligand (a). In 4, center mental Cu1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three I ions and one N atom from DABCO, and Cu2 is coordinated by four I ions. The distance of Cu-Cu interaction is ca. 2.919(4) Å, which is similar to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu atoms, indicating the existence of weak Cu-Cu interactions. Each iodine ion adopts μ2-I or μ3-I bridging modes. A prominent structural feature of 4 is four Cu ions connected by three I atoms resulting in an unique single cap hexagon-like Cu4I3 unit (b), while connection of the Cu4I3 units by bridging iodine ion results in 6-ring window with six Cu4I3 clusters. The diameter of the 6-ring is approximately 1.48 nm. Every 6-ring is surrounded by another six 6-rings, which form a 2D layer without effective free volume (c,d). Note that even by omitting DABCO ligand, only by inorganic compositions (Cu and I), the 2D layer can be constructed.

elements.content: Compared with the synthesis and structure between 3 and 4, it could be indicated that structure-directing agents play a remarkable role on the formation of cuprous iodide cluster based metal–organic complexes. We speculate that the uncoordinated H3TPCB molecules in 3 act as additive agents, which not only can change pH value of the system resulting in various [CuI] n clusters but also induce the microporosity 2D network due to the size large enough. Without H3TPCB molecules, DABCO is too small, which cannot hold up the hole in 4. Coordinated H2O molecules and monodentate DABCO molecules as terminal tailors reduce the connectivity of [CuI] n nodes and prevent the 2D layers from extending to 3D frameworks in 3 and 4, respectively. We could conclude that the additive agent is necessary and plays a key role in constructing microporosity structure.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of 1 was confirmed by performing the N2 adsorption experiments at 77 K. As displayed in Figure S7, the N2 adsorption of the activated sample complex 1 presents the type I adsorption isotherm, showing the microporous nature of the framework, which is consistent with the observed channels in the crystal structure analysis. The N2 adsorption amount of complex 1 at 1 bar is about 121.7 cm3 g–1, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be ca. 416 m2 g–1.
elements.clean_text:
Porosity Characterization

The permanent porosity of 1 was confirmed by performing the N2 adsorption experiments at 77 K. As displayed in Figure S7, the N2 adsorption of the activated sample complex 1 presents the type I adsorption isotherm, showing the microporous nature of the framework, which is consistent with the observed channels in the crystal structure analysis. The N2 adsorption amount of complex 1 at 1 bar is about 121.7 cm3 g-1, and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be ca. 416 m2 g-1.

elements.content: Motivated by the structure character of opening windows in 1, it is feasible to utilize activated complex 1 to capture molecules. We selected six different dye molecules to measure the absorption ability of 1. Positively charged Methylene Blue (MEB), Crystal Violet (CV), Rhodamine B (RB), and negatively charged Methyl Orange (MO) and Methyl Blue (MB), and neutral Indigo Blue (IB) were first checked (). The selected dyes have characteristic peaks, such as the main adsorption peak of IB is at 628 nm, MEB at 663 nm, MO at 466 nm, CV at 581 nm, RB at 554 nm, and MB at 594 nm. Typically, 10 mg of freshly prepared crystals 1 were added in aqueous solutions of the above dyes at room temperature. With increasing time, UV–vis adsorption spectroscopy was used to confirm the adsorption abilities of 1 toward the above dyes (). The results illuminate that cationic dye CV could be absorbed within a period of time efficiently. At the same time, the color of crystals is gradually from green to dark blue in aqueous solutions of CV, whereas in other dyes (i.e., IB, MEB, MO, RB, and MB) colors were not detected. The distinguishing characteristics in absorption behaviors among the six types of dyes may be the size and shape exclusion, such as the shape of CV is triangle-planar and “just right” size, not too big and not too small, compared with others, i.e. IB, MEB, and MO, which are linear and too small, RB and MB are too large. The results imply that the adsorption behavior of 1 should be the size and shape exclusion effect. The following equations are used to calculate the adsorption efficiency and the quantity: efficiency ( % ) = C 0 − C x C 0 × 100 Q ( quantity ) = C 0 − C X m × V where the C 0 is the initial concentration of dye solution and the C x represents the concentration of 1 that adsorbs the dyes at x min, and m is the mass of the complex we used. We tested the ability of absorbing dyes at room temperature setting without shocking. Within 30 min, about 46.76% of CV was captured (d). Then we continue this experiment for 240 min, we found that 98.49% of CV was absorbed. The concentration was decreased to confirm the absorption quantity of 1, and at the end of the experiment, 1 g of complex 1 could adsorb 0.123 mmol of CV, compared with other dyes, which were hardly absorbed by 1.
elements.clean_text:
Selective Adsorption and Release of Dyes in 1 

Motivated by the structure character of opening windows in 1, it is feasible to utilize activated complex 1 to capture molecules. We selected six different dye molecules to measure the absorption ability of 1. Positively charged Methylene Blue (MEB), Crystal Violet (CV), Rhodamine B (RB), and negatively charged Methyl Orange (MO) and Methyl Blue (MB), and neutral Indigo Blue (IB) were first checked (). The selected dyes have characteristic peaks, such as the main adsorption peak of IB is at 628 nm, MEB at 663 nm, MO at 466 nm, CV at 581 nm, RB at 554 nm, and MB at 594 nm. Typically, 10 mg of freshly prepared crystals 1 were added in aqueous solutions of the above dyes at room temperature. With increasing time, UV-vis adsorption spectroscopy was used to confirm the adsorption abilities of 1 toward the above dyes (). The results illuminate that cationic dye CV could be absorbed within a period of time efficiently. At the same time, the color of crystals is gradually from green to dark blue in aqueous solutions of CV, whereas in other dyes (i.e., IB, MEB, MO, RB, and MB) colors were not detected. The distinguishing characteristics in absorption behaviors among the six types of dyes may be the size and shape exclusion, such as the shape of CV is triangle-planar and "just right" size, not too big and not too small, compared with others, i.e. IB, MEB, and MO, which are linear and too small, RB and MB are too large. The results imply that the adsorption behavior of 1 should be the size and shape exclusion effect. The following equations are used to calculate the adsorption efficiency and the quantity: 1    efficiency  ( % )  =     C   0   -   C   x       C   0     × 100     2    Q  ( quantity )  =     C   0   -   C   X     m   × V   where the C 0 is the initial concentration of dye solution and the C  x  represents the concentration of 1 that adsorbs the dyes at x min, and m is the mass of the complex we used. We tested the ability of absorbing dyes at room temperature setting without shocking. Within 30 min, about 46.76% of CV was captured (d). Then we continue this experiment for 240 min, we found that 98.49% of CV was absorbed. The concentration was decreased to confirm the absorption quantity of 1, and at the end of the experiment, 1 g of complex 1 could adsorb 0.123 mmol of CV, compared with other dyes, which were hardly absorbed by 1.

elements.content: In addition, to confirm whether the adsorbent could be recycled and reused in the practical application is extremely important; thus, the dye-releasing experiments were also performed in pure water and the saturated aqueous solution of NH4Cl, respectively. The results suggest that the CV can hardly be released from CV@1 in pure water, while when NH4Cl was the trigger, CV@1 was be gradually released (). In this case, we could find that the adsorption of CV in 1 is accompanied by the ion exchange as stated above.

elements.content: The stability of 1 after adsorbing CV and releasing CV in NH4Cl is detected by the PXRD data (Figure S8). Most worthy of mention is when the crystals were soaked in the aqueous solution of CV, some peaks of PXRD patterns became weak, while when the CV was removed from the complex upon immersion of the crystals in NH4Cl saturated aqueous solution the peaks strengthened again. This phenomenon can be well explained that a high amount of CV in 1 has a significant impact on the sensitivity of X-rays, but does not affect the stability of the crystal.

elements.content: Furthermore, the exploration about the selective separation of different dyes is more significant. On the basis of the foregoing experiences, we continue studying the selective adsorption capacity of CV from mixtures of CV and MO. CV and MO were selected so that the color is unambiguous and the peak spacing is bigger. Spectroscopic study suggested CV could be preferentially captured within the pores of 1 over a period of time, while MO could not be incorporated (a). In a word, we can conclude that CV can be separated from CV and MO in aqueous solution. It was found that different dyes, just right size and triangular Crystal Violet (CV), can be rapidly adsorbed by 1, but smaller and linear Methyl Orange (MO) can hardly be adsorbed (). From the above experiments, 1 can preferentially adsorbs CV from MO and CV in their mixed aqueous solution, and the crystalline integrity of 1 is maintained after the successful selective absorbing of CV, which can be further confirmed by PXRD (Figure S8). It was demonstrated that 1 might be a favorable adsorbent for removing CV dyes efficiently and selectively.

elements.content: We have further investigated the separation behavior of CV from mixtures of CV and MO. As depicted in a, the entry of CV into the 1 host framework results in a distinct decrease of the absorption. The decline of the absorption also indicates that 1 can quickly separate CV. To measure tunable sensitivity to time quantitatively for 1, we consider introducing the concept of relative sensitivity. b shows the ratio of the absorption for MO (∼466 nm) and CV (∼581 nm) of 1 versus time, normalized to the absorption ratio at 1.16667. There is a good linear relationship between the absorption ratio and time in the range of 0 to 240 min, which can be fitted as a function of A 466 / A 481 = 0.680 + 0.038 ( t ) with correlation coefficient 0.9814, where A 466 and A 481 is the absorption of MO and CV, respectively, and t is the time of adsorption CV into the 1 host framework (min). The relative sensitivity is defined as S = | ∂ P / ∂ t P | where P is the measured time-sensitive parameter, for example, absorption, lifetime, intensity, or absorption ratio. For time-sensitivity, the relative sensitivity can be determined as S = | ∂ ( A 1 / A 2 ) / ∂ t A 1 / A 2 | where A 1 and A 2 is the absorption of MO and CV, respectively. According to the definition, the sensitivity of 1 is calculated to be 0.372% min–1. Calculations from signal-to-noise ratios by a UV–vis spectrometer display that a 0.1% change of absorption ratio can be readily measured, which implies that the theoretical maximum sensing resolution of 1 could be faster than 16.13 s. On the basis of the preliminary results, the calculation of relative sensitivity revealed that 1 can separate CV from mixtures of CV and MO rapidly and sensitively.

elements.content: Chemical compositions play significant influence in the optical properties. The synthesis of the same composition materials with different dimensions provides a great opportunity for exploring impact of chemical compositions on electronic band gaps. In addition, the novel copper–iodine cluster complexes 3 and 4 possess flexible μ-I linkage modes, metallophillic interactions, and electron-rich feature, so it is beneficial to study their semiconductor properties. Thus, we have recorded the optical absorption spectra by ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflection method in the solid state (a) and investigated the optical absorption spectra of the two complexes based on the Kubelka–Munk function, (F(R) = (1 – R)2/2R). The optical band gaps are 2.37 and 1.98 eV for 3 and 4, respectively (b). In general, the band gap of the framework decreases usually along with the framework density increasing. This correlation also seems to hold here. The layered microporous network of 3 (ρ = 2.786 g cm–3) is less dense than the inorganic constituent constructed framework of 4 (ρ = 3.526 g cm–3). Therefore, the latter one displays a smaller band gap. Meanwhile, by comparing the UV absorption spectra of pure DABCO ligand and complex 3, the absorption between 200 and 310 nm should be attributed to DABCO ligand (Figure S9), while the peak above 320 nm is reasonably assigned to the presence of [CuI] n clusters. Beyond that, due to the existence of the inorganic cuprous iodide layers, the corresponding Cu4I3 absorption of 4 becomes much stronger than that in 3. Therefore, 4 displays a much broader peak (between 200 to 600 nm) that contains the absorption areas of both DABCO ligand and complex 3. The results demonstrate that once the dimensions of inorganic compositions increased, the band gap would observably decrease, which can be supported by TD-DFT calculation (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text:
Optical Absorption Spectra

Chemical compositions play significant influence in the optical properties. The synthesis of the same composition materials with different dimensions provides a great opportunity for exploring impact of chemical compositions on electronic band gaps. In addition, the novel copper-iodine cluster complexes 3 and 4 possess flexible μ-I linkage modes, metallophillic interactions, and electron-rich feature, so it is beneficial to study their semiconductor properties. Thus, we have recorded the optical absorption spectra by ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) diffuse reflection method in the solid state (a) and investigated the optical absorption spectra of the two complexes based on the Kubelka-Munk function, (F(R) = (1 - R)2/2R). The optical band gaps are 2.37 and 1.98 eV for 3 and 4, respectively (b). In general, the band gap of the framework decreases usually along with the framework density increasing. This correlation also seems to hold here. The layered microporous network of 3 (ρ = 2.786 g cm-3) is less dense than the inorganic constituent constructed framework of 4 (ρ = 3.526 g cm-3). Therefore, the latter one displays a smaller band gap. Meanwhile, by comparing the UV absorption spectra of pure DABCO ligand and complex 3, the absorption between 200 and 310 nm should be attributed to DABCO ligand (Figure S9), while the peak above 320 nm is reasonably assigned to the presence of [CuI] n  clusters. Beyond that, due to the existence of the inorganic cuprous iodide layers, the corresponding Cu4I3 absorption of 4 becomes much stronger than that in 3. Therefore, 4 displays a much broader peak (between 200 to 600 nm) that contains the absorption areas of both DABCO ligand and complex 3. The results demonstrate that once the dimensions of inorganic compositions increased, the band gap would observably decrease, which can be supported by TD-DFT calculation (Figure S10).

elements.content: In summary, we have obtained four new metal–organic complexes, which are successfully synthesized through Cu­(I) salts solvothermally reacting with the novel multifunctional C 3 rotating shaft ligand H3TPCB. The structural diversities of the complexes illustrate that the H3TPCB ligand takes various configurations and coordination modes to construct fascinating structures. Depending on the pore size in the framework, 1 displays fast and efficient CV uptake following the size and shape selective effect, and releases CV easily with the help of NH4 +. Notably, 1 can preferentially adsorb CV from MO and CV in their mixed aqueous solution with fast response (<16.13 s). The diffuse reflection spectra reveal that 3 and 4 have band gaps of 2.37 and 1.98 eV, respectively. Thus, this work will offer more insight into the structure–property relationships, and MOCs are also the promising dye adsorption and semiconductor materials for future application.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have obtained four new metal-organic complexes, which are successfully synthesized through Cu(I) salts solvothermally reacting with the novel multifunctional C 3 rotating shaft ligand H3TPCB. The structural diversities of the complexes illustrate that the H3TPCB ligand takes various configurations and coordination modes to construct fascinating structures. Depending on the pore size in the framework, 1 displays fast and efficient CV uptake following the size and shape selective effect, and releases CV easily with the help of NH4 +. Notably, 1 can preferentially adsorb CV from MO and CV in their mixed aqueous solution with fast response (<16.13 s). The diffuse reflection spectra reveal that 3 and 4 have band gaps of 2.37 and 1.98 eV, respectively. Thus, this work will offer more insight into the structure-property relationships, and MOCs are also the promising dye adsorption and semiconductor materials for future application.

Green hexagon-shaped crystals were dried at room temperature (yield ca. 74%, based on H3TCPB). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd. for C54H40Cu3O23 (M r : 1247.48): C, 51.99; H, 3.23%. cln_elements.content: The permanent porosity of 1 was confirmed by performing the N2 adsorption experiments at 77 K. As displayed in Figure S7, the N2 adsorption of the activated sample complex 1 presents the type I adsorption isotherm, showing the microporous nature of the framework, which is consistent with the observed channels in the crystal structure analysis. The N2 adsorption amount of complex 1 at 1 bar is about 121.7 cm3 g–1, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be ca. 416 m2 g–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Porosity Characterization

The permanent porosity of 1 was confirmed by performing the N2 adsorption experiments at 77 K. As displayed in Figure S7, the N2 adsorption of the activated sample complex 1 presents the type I adsorption isotherm, showing the microporous nature of the framework, which is consistent with the observed channels in the crystal structure analysis. The N2 adsorption amount of complex 1 at 1 bar is about 121.7 cm3 g-1, and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be ca. 416 m2 g-1.

Insight into the Controllable Synthesis of Cu(I)/Cu(II)
Metal–Organic Complexes: Size-Exclusive Selective Dye Adsorption
and Semiconductor Properties
